project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In a case where there is a ticket that is already has a set of number approval needed to proceed, it would not be changed even the Approval Configuration in the Workflow is changed. Let's say that in the ticket it needs 1 and later in the workflow, it changed that it needs 2, the same ticket will say that it is still 1.

h3. Steps to Replicate
# Edit an existing JIRA Service Desk Workflow.
# Configure a certain status to have 1 Approval needed.
# Publish the workflow.
# Create a ticket and transitioned it to the same status.
# Set 2 user as the Approval while it only needs 1.
# Edit the workflow again and change the Approval need all user to approve.
# Publish and check the ticket again.

h3. Expected Result
- The ticket will be updated with 2 Approval Needed.

h3. Actual Result
- The ticket still needs only 1 Approval.

h3. Note
- In case that JIRA Service Desk would like to retain the Issue Approval History, such information is not given in the documentation below:
-* [Setting up Approval|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver/setting-up-approvals-939926369.html]
fields.summary: Changes on Approval Configuration does not affect existing ticket

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Attachments cannot be previewed or downloaded from Customer Portal

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open the affected issue in the Customer portal
 # Look for thumbnails or attachments in comments, and try to download them.

h3. Expected Results
The attachment thumbnails are visible and you can download them as usual.

h3. Actual Results
The image preview is shown as a grey rectangle instead of the actual thumbnail. Clicking in the image will either do nothing or cause an error. When the issue is loaded, it will log an error like this:

h3. Notes
* It was identified by our dev team that the problem here is that the affected issues have a NULL description, as opposed to empty string. We can't tell this from Jira interface because NULL and empty string look the same in the Jira issue view.
* In the developer tools an error 500 will be thrown in this scenario.

- Short term workaround: add a description to the impacted request (any character added to it will fix the inconsistency)
- Long term workaround: make the description field mandatory in *Project Settings > Request Types*, to ensure that the description field is never empty

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When accessing linked issues through the Service Desk queue, if the issue from the target project *does not* have a linked knowledge base while the source project does, Jira will not display any comments in the linked issue, and also will not allow users to insert new comments on it. After refreshing the page, this behavior does not happen. 

h3. Environment

* Jira Service Desk 3.16.1
* Confluence 6.15.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an issue in a project that *does* have a linked knowledge base on Confluence
# Access the created issue, then click on *More > Create linked issue*
# Create a linked issue in a project that *does not* have a linked knowledge base on Confluence
# Add a comment in the linked issue
# Access the source issue through *Project > Queues*
# Click on the linked issue to access it

h3. Expected Results

Jira will display the linked issue with all comments, and will allow the user to add a comment there

h3. Actual Results

All comments will be missing and the user won't be able to add a new comment there.

h3. Workaround

Refresh the page.
fields.summary: Comments missing when accessing linked issues through Service Desk's queue

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
In some specific SLA configurations, data from "Resolved" & "Time to Resolution" series don't match for the chosen period (SLA met + SLA breached not equal to Resolved).

This can happen if "Status: Resolved" event is used in "Pause on" condition:
 !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail! 

This behaviour is caused by the fact that:
* "Resolved" series uses "Resolved" date as a counting reference
* "Time to Resolution" uses start and end timestamps of the SLA cycle as a counting reference

In this example, if the ticket gets resolved in January, the SLA will get paused, which means "Time to Resolution" won't include this ticket in the report for January.

We suggest consolidating these report series, so that the same date values are being used to count tickets against these series.
fields.summary: Time to Resolution and Resolved report display different number of tickets due to different criteria used to count the issues

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When a user views an SD ticket from Customer Portal, JSD only shows attachments from the *first 50 comments that are viewable* by the user:
* For a customer, this means the first 50 *public* comments 
* For an agent, this means the first 50 comments _regardless of public or internal_, as long as the agent can view them all from Jira Issue View

Attachments added to any comment after the 50th viewable one can't be viewed or downloaded as JSD throws a 403 Forbidden error.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a new SD ticket
# Add 49 public comments and 1 internal comment to it, without any attachments
# Add comment #51 as public, with an attachment
(i) This can be done by either agent or customer from either Jira or Portal. Observe these behaviors:
#* From Portal, customer can view/download the attachment, as it's in the 50th comment viewable by him (/)
#* From Portal, agent can't view/download the attachment, as it's in the 51st comment viewable by him (-)
#* From Jira, agent can view/download/manage the attachment normally (+)
# Add comment #52 as public, with a different attachment that has a different file name
(i) This can be done by either agent or customer from either Jira or Portal. Observe these behaviors:
#* From Portal, customer can't view/download the attachment, as it's in the 51st comment viewable by him (-)
#* From Portal, agent can't view/download the attachment, as it's in the 52nd comment viewable by him (-)
#* From Jira, agent can view/download/manage the attachment normally (+)

h3. Expected Results
Attachments should be able to be viewed/downloaded from Portal regardless of where it appears.

h3. Actual Results
A 403 Forbidden error is thrown for attachments added after the 50th viewable comment relative to the user.

h3. Workarounds
h4. Workaround 1 - Recommended
# As an agent, find a *public* comment that is among the *first 50 comments* (including both public and internal comments)
# Edit that comment and add wiki markup for the attachment

(+) This way, the attachment is seen by JSD as appearing in 1 of the first 50 comments viewable by both customers and agents. Both customers and agents should then be able to view it from Portal.

h4. Workaround 2 - only applicable to customers
As an agent, convert older public comments to internal so that the attachment now appears in one of the first 50 public comments. Customers should then be able to view it.

(flag) This won't help agents as internal comments are still viewable by them.

h4. Workaround 3 - only applicable to agents
View the ticket in Jira instead of Portal.
fields.summary: Users can't view Attachments added after the 50th Viewable Comment to them on Customer Portal

# They have 15 teams users, each team is from a different country.
# There are 4 priorities.
# Since these 15 teams are from different countries, a different calendar is needed for different public holiday.
# If we configure it with usual JIRA Service Desk SLA configurations, we need to:-
** Create 15 Calendar for each of the countries 
** Write JQL Query to filter out:-
*** User Team (countries)
*** Priority
*** Issue type 
# Since we are having 4 different priority and 15 countries, we need to configure 4 JQL queries for each of the countries. Which in total 60 configurations.
# If we have different issue type need to be configured. It would be double or even triple up the numbers of configurations.
# It would be glad if we could have an easier way to configure SLA goal for multiple calendars.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Whenever the "Include Customer Logins" option is disabled through Jira's SAML configuration, customers are allowed to log in through their system credentials while not going through SAML. If Agents log in through this method and access the customer portal successfully, they can re-write the URL pointing to a Jira admin section and it loads without any SAML validation. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Set up Jira with SAML
 # Set up Service Desk
 # Configure an Agent
 # Un-check the "Include customer logins" option
 # Log in with the Agent through the Customer Portal URL: /servicedesk/customer/portal/1
 # The login should go through successfully and you'll see the customer portal page
 # Edit the URL to point to a Service Desk project configuration: servicedesk/admin/TES/request-types/group/1

h3. Expected Results

SAML would request an authentication to validate the user.

h3. Actual Results

The page renders successfully without requesting for any additional login or validation.

h3. Workaround

Enable Include Customer Logins yet again.
fields.summary: While "Include customer logins" is not checked, agents logged in as Customers can access Jira admin without SAML authentication

fields.description:
As a service desk manager, I would like to be able to select and order which dashboards appear on my left hand navigation.

Currently the order is comprised of newly added dashboards (temporal order) and there is a ticket [JSDSERVER-1529|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1529] that suggests alphabetic order.  However, there is no control to add or remove desks from this list.  One needs to use arcane navigation to get to a desk without having control over lists.

I would like to suggest instead, or in addition, that a "Configure sidebar" funtion be offered similar in design to that of Confluence, where the user is given control of both the entries and order to the lefthand navigation menu; in this case, available dashboards.

One might also consider that this might be more useful to staff and management in service organizations whose roles will have stronger influence on purchasing decisions for the product. Thanks for listening.
fields.summary: Dashboards - configure sidebar - for items and order

fields.description:
h3. Summary

The customer satisfaction report is always missing the most recent survey.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Install Service Desk 4.0.x
# Create a Service Desk project
# Open 1 request from the Customer portal
# Resolve this request
# Wait for the customer satisfaction survey and rate the request
# Open the Customer Satisfaction report
# Repeat the same steps to rate a 2nd request
# Open the Customer Satisfaction report again

h3. Expected Results

- The first time the Customer Satisfaction report is opened, we should see 1 survey
- The 2nd time the Customer Satisfaction report is opened, we should see 2 surveys

h3. Actual Results

- The first time the Customer Satisfaction report is opened, we don't see any survey:
 !SatisfactionReport_1survey.png|thumbnail! 
- The 2nd time the Customer Satisfaction report is opened, we only see 1 survey (the most recent survey is missing)
 !SatisfactionReport_2survey.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Note

Looking into the API call made by satisfaction report, we can see that the start index is incorrect: it starts with 1 instead of 0:
- API call:
{code}
<JIRA_BASE_URL>/rest/servicedesk/1/projects/SDTEST/report/feedback?start=1&limit=20&jsonFilter=%7B%22timescaleId%22%3A2%7D&expand=overall&_=1552917400224
{code}
- Result:
{code}
{"summary":{"average":5.0,"count":2.0},"pagedResults":{"results":[{"agentName":"julien","agentDisplayName":"Julien Rey","agentAvatar":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/81b27be715d86f51a84b5d87ed547fd4?d=mm&s=16","agentNotActive":false,"requestTypeName":"Employee exit","requestTypeIcon":10526,"rating":5,"comment":"Hell yeah!","feedbackDate":"Yesterday 3:32 PM","issueKey":"SDTEST-5","issueUrl":"/jira800/projects/SDTEST/issue/SDTEST-5"}],"size":2,"start":1,"limit":20,"totalPages":1}}
{code}

If the API Call is manually modified to start with index 0 instead, then both surveys are returned as expected:

- API call:
{code}
<JIRA_BASE_URL>/rest/servicedesk/1/projects/SDTEST/report/feedback?start=0&limit=20&jsonFilter=%7B%22timescaleId%22%3A2%7D&expand=overall&_=1552917400224
{code}
- Result:
{code}
{"summary":{"average":5.0,"count":2.0},"pagedResults":{"results":[{"agentName":"julien","agentDisplayName":"Julien Rey","agentAvatar":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/81b27be715d86f51a84b5d87ed547fd4?d=mm&s=16","agentNotActive":false,"requestTypeName":"New employee","requestTypeIcon":10531,"rating":5,"comment":"Test","feedbackDate":"Yesterday 3:35 PM","issueKey":"SDTEST-6","issueUrl":"/jira800/projects/SDTEST/issue/SDTEST-6"},{"agentName":"julien","agentDisplayName":"Julien Rey","agentAvatar":"https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/81b27be715d86f51a84b5d87ed547fd4?d=mm&s=16","agentNotActive":false,"requestTypeName":"Employee exit","requestTypeIcon":10526,"rating":5,"comment":"Hell yeah!","feedbackDate":"Yesterday 3:32 PM","issueKey":"SDTEST-5","issueUrl":"/jira800/projects/SDTEST/issue/SDTEST-5"}],"size":2,"start":0,"limit":20,"totalPages":1}}
{code}

h3. Workaround

No known workaround for now

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Can't save changes when Editing the Service Requests report
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In a Service Desk project, go to Project settings > Reports.
 # Go to the Bundled Report "Service requests"
 # Click the Edit button !screenshot-1.png|thumbnail!
 # Try to edit any metric and save (even without changing anything): !screenshot-2.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results

The changes are saved
h3. Actual Results

Nothing happens when clicking the Save button.
h3. Notes
 * Only the Support requests report shows this issue.
 * When generating a HAR file, you get an error: jqlTooComplex
 * Issue not present in Jira 7.13

h3. Workaround
The error is caused by the the JQL being incorrect and JSD silently swallowing the error.
The JQL is incorrect because the report is created with the wrong request type. You can fix existing projects by the following steps:
# In the affected project, go to Project settings > Reports.
# Go to the Bundled Report "Service requests"
# Click the Edit button.
# Click "Edit" below the "IT Help" series.
# In the "Filter by" text box, change "IT Help" to "Get IT help".
# Click the Save button on the "Edit a series" dialog.
# Click the Save button.
fields.summary: Can't save changes when Editing the Service Requests report

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

When a JIRA user is added as participant of a Service Desk request, this user should be treated as a customer and therefore should not be able to receive any JIRA Core notification (notifications configured in the Notification Scheme, and meant for agent users).

This behavior:
- is described in the documentation [Managing service desk notifications|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver/managing-service-desk-notifications-939926348.html]
- is addressed in the feature request [JSDSERVER-6248|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-6248]

There are 2 scenarios where the notification mechanism is not consistent:
- *Scenario 1:* if a user is a participant of a Service Desk request and mentioned in an internal comment, this user won't receive a JIRA Core notification from this comment (expected behavior)
- *Scenario 2:* if a user is *both a participant and a watcher* of the ticket and mentioned in an internal comment, then this user will receive a JIRA Core notification from this comment (unexpected behavior)

The inconsistency between these 2 scenarios does not seem to be intentional therefore is a bug.

h3. +Expected behavior+

We would expected both scenarios to lead to the same result: in both cases, the user should not receive any notification from an internal comment, since this user should be treated as a customer.

Therefore, the scenario 1 is correct (based on the design), but not the scenario 2.
fields.summary: Inconsistency with how JIRA Core notifications are sent to users treated as Customers

fields.description:
h3. Summary

If "Assign issue" permission is not provided to Portal Customers, they will be unable to share request with other customers.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Service Desk Project
 # Grant User's Permission to share request to anyone.
 # Go to the permission scheme and remove the "Assign Issue Permission" from "Service desk customer - portal access" role
 # Logged as a Portal Customer, create a request and try to share it.

h3. Expected Results

Once you enter the email address of the person you want to share the request with, you hit "Add" and the participant should be included on the ticket.
h3. Actual Results

Hitting "Add" will not include the other user as a participant. The error message below shows in the network tab / HAR file:
{code:java}
{"errors":[{"errorMessage":"Failed to update request participants field, errors: You do not have permission to assign issues."}],"reasonKey":"sd.request.participants.error.field.update.failed","reasonCode":"500"} {code}
h3. Workaround
 * JIRA Service Desk will detect this permission inconsistency and will show a pop-up window, suggesting the resolution of the issue.  !sd_permissions_repair.png!
 * Manually Add 'Service desk customer - portal access' role to the permission scheme
fields.summary: Customers are unable to share request if "Assign issue" permission is not provided

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When a user views an issue in JIRA or Service Desk queue, the lastViewed date of that issue is updated for the user, hence searching using lastViewed works. However, if the user views an issue in Customer Portal, lastViewed is not updated.

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Identify 2 issues that haven't been viewed since yesterday
# View one of them in JIRA or Service Desk queue
# View the other in Customer Portal
# Go to Issue Navigator and search with:
{code}lastViewed >= startOfDay(){code}

h3. Expected behavior
Both issues are returned.

h3. Actual behavior
Only the one viewed in JIRA or Service Desk queue is returned. The one viewed in Customer Portal is not.

h3. Notes
# This may be an expected behavior, whereby the issue viewer from Customer Portal may be a customer who doesn't have access to JIRA and hence can't perform a JQL search.
# This mostly affects SD agents who can view issues both in JIRA/SD queue and Customer Portal.

h3. Workaround
View the issues in JIRA/SD queue instead of Customer Portal.
fields.summary: lastViewed should be counted when viewing issue from Customer Portal

fields.description:
When searching for issues ordered by an SLA’s remaining time, including while viewing queues and filter gadgets, the search occasionally fails with the following error on the server:

{code}java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.metric.DateTimeRange - the START time of the DateTimeRange (2019-01-31T16:45:56.370Z) must be less than or equal to the STOP time (2019-01-31T16:45:37.941
    at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.metric.DateTimeRange.<init>(DateTimeRange.java:37)
    at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.searcher.sorter.SlaOrderingCalculationServiceImpl.getRemainingTimeSortingData(SlaOrderingCalculationServiceImpl.java:51)
    at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.searcher.sorter.RemainingTimeSorter.getValueFromLuceneField(RemainingTimeSorter.java:62)
    at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.sla.searcher.sorter.RemainingTimeSorter.getValueFromLuceneField(RemainingTimeSorter.java:27)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.parameters.lucene.sort.MappedSortComparator.getComparable(MappedSortComparator.java:179)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.parameters.lucene.sort.JiraLuceneFieldFinder.getCustom(JiraLuceneFieldFinder.java:64)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.parameters.lucene.sort.MappedSortComparator.getLuceneValues(MappedSortComparator.java:162)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.parameters.lucene.sort.MappedSortComparator$HungryValueFinder.getValue(MappedSortComparator.java:221)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.parameters.lucene.sort.MappedSortComparator$InternalFieldComparator.getDocumentValue(MappedSortComparator.java:119)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.parameters.lucene.sort.MappedSortComparator$InternalFieldComparator.copy(MappedSortComparator.java:95)
    at org.apache.lucene.search.TopFieldCollector$MultiComparatorNonScoringCollector.collect(TopFieldCollector.java:434)
    at org.apache.lucene.search.IndexSearcher.searchWithFilter(IndexSearcher.java:572)
    at org.apache.lucene.search.IndexSearcher.search(IndexSearcher.java:532)
    at org.apache.lucene.search.IndexSearcher.search(IndexSearcher.java:463)
    at org.apache.lucene.search.IndexSearcher.search(IndexSearcher.java:433)
    at org.apache.lucene.search.IndexSearcher.search(IndexSearcher.java:356)
    at com.atlassian.jira.index.DelegateSearcher.search(DelegateSearcher.java:142)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.providers.LuceneSearchProvider.searchDocuments(LuceneSearchProvider.java:467)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.providers.LuceneSearchProvider.runSearch(LuceneSearchProvider.java:449)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.providers.LuceneSearchProvider.getHits(LuceneSearchProvider.java:217)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.providers.LuceneSearchProvider.search(LuceneSearchProvider.java:340)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.providers.LuceneSearchProvider.search(LuceneSearchProvider.java:114)
    at com.atlassian.jira.issue.search.providers.LuceneSearchProvider.search(LuceneSearchProvider.java:110)
    ... 2 filtered{code}

h3. Causes

SlaOrderingCalculationService#getRemainingTimeSortingData is called with “data” and “now” arguments such that data.shiftedStartDate > now, which in turn violates the DateTimeRange constructor’s contract.

The exact root cause is uncertain, but one possibility might be the creation of new issues during a long-running search. RemainingTimeSorter calculates the remaining time of each issue using its ongoing cycle’s start time and the current time, and the latter is cached for the duration of the search for deterministic results, making the ongoing cycles of affected issues appear to start in the future.

h3. Workarounds

There are no known workarounds yet, other than retrying the affected searches.
fields.summary: Uncaught exception in DateTimeRange when ordering search results by an SLA custom field

h3. Summary

When administrator adds an additional validator to the "Create" transition and user tried to create an issue (which is using the workflow with the additional validator) from Customer portal, the issue creation will fail with following error if user did not fulfill the validator:

{quote}
Your request could not be created. Please check the fields have been correctly filled in.
{quote}

Jira Service Desk 3.16.0, 3.16.1

Following error shown in Customer Portal:

{quote}
Your request could not be created. Please check the fields have been correctly filled in.
{quote}

Remove the validator that requires the field on Create Issue transition on the workflow.

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

Customer notifications are not working (they are not sent) in Service Desk 4.0.1 when connecting to a MS SQL database.
h3. +Steps to reproduce+
 # Install a fresh JSD 4.0.1 instance
 # Connect it to a MS SQL database by following the instructions in [Connecting JIRA to MS SQL 2014|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/connecting-jira-applications-to-sql-server-2014-938846861.html]
 # Configure an outgoing mail server in ⚙ > System > Outgoing Mail
 !CustomerNotification_Bug_Step1.png|thumbnail!
 # Create a new Service Desk project
 # Log into the customer portal with a customer account
 # Create a new SD request
 !CustomerNotification_Bug_Step2.png|thumbnail!
 # Open the request from the agent view, by logging with an agent account, and add a public comment
 !CustomerNotification_Bug_Step3.png|thumbnail!

h3. +Expected Result+

The customer should have received 2 customer notifications
 - the request created notification
 - the public comment added notification

h3. +Actual Result+

The customer did not receive any notification.

In fact, the table which contains the customer notification (AO_4E8AE6_NOTIF_BATCH_QUEUE) is completely empty, which means that no notification is created at all.

The following query returns no result at all:
{code:java}
SELECT * FROM jiraschema.AO_4E8AE6_NOTIF_BATCH_QUEUE;
{code}
h3. +Workaround+

*If you are using JIRA with JAVA 8*

# Stop JIRA
# Move the MS SQL driver mssql-jdbc-7.2.0.jre8.jar from the folder below (please make a backup of it or move it to a temporary folder)
{code:java}
<JIRA_INSTALLATION_FOLDER>/lib
{code}
# Copy the driver  [^mssql-jdbc-6.2.1.jre8.jar] to the same folder
# Start JIRA

*If you are using JIRA with Java 11*

Please note that we do not have a fully tested workaround for JIRA running with Java 11 and involving the replacement of the ms sql jdbc driver.

For this reason, as a workaround, what you can do is either downgrade to your previous version or 4.0.0 of Service Desk, which are both unaffected by this problem. Here are the steps you can follow to execute a downgrade. 8.0.0 might be your best bet since it's a closer down version to what you are on:

# Download the Jira ServiceDesk 4.0.0 Server installer from the link below to install Jira Core 8.0.0 + Service Desk 4.0.0: [Update Jira Service Desk Server|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/service-desk/update]. You will want to click on *View all versions* to get to the 4.0.0 installer for Windows.
# Install Jira Service Desk Server 4.0.0 as a new separate standalone instance as a medium for the 'downgrade'. That being said, there should be a new {{JIRA_Home}}, {{JIRA_Installation}}, and new database for this Service Desk 4.0.0 instance on a new server.
# Once this new instance (4.0.0) is ready, shut it down.
# Allocate adequate application memory as per the [Jira Sizing Guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/enterprise/jira-sizing-guide-461504623.html] and set the flag {{-Djira.downgrade.allowed=true}} on the JSD 4.0.0 instance as per our [Setting properties and options on startup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver070/setting-properties-and-options-on-startup-749383528.html] documentation for your new Windows instance. (i) This is to allow the downgrade to run properly.
# Start the new 4.0.0 instance of Service Desk.
# Take a latest XML backup from your 4.0.1 Service Desk instance that you currently have that is encountering these issues.
# Restore the backup into the new 4.0.0 instance. There will be a message that needs to be acknowledged on the UI after selecting the backup for restoration. Acknowledge it, verify the correct backup file has been chosen and then click on the Restore button again to kick start the restoration process.
# Once this is done, your user will be logged out. Re-login to the 4.0.0 instance, ensure the JSD application is installed and licensed, and that you are able to run automation and send out notifications to customers on some test issues.

h3. +Important Note+

Other Service Desk functionalities are also impacted in Service Desk 4.0.1, when running with a MS SQL Database:
- [SLA panel is empty when new issues are created and SLA does not stop/pause, when using MS SQL with JSD 4.0.1|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-6251]
- [Service Desk automation rules are no longer triggered when using MS SQL with JSD 4.0.1|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-6252]
fields.summary: Customer notifications are no longer created and sent when using MS-SQL with JSD 4.0.1

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

Service Desk automation rules are no longer triggered in Service Desk 4.0.1 when connecting to a MS SQL database.
h3. +Steps to reproduce+
 # Install a fresh JSD 4.0.1 instance
 # Connect it to a MS SQL database by following the instructions in [Connecting JIRA to MS SQL 2014|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/connecting-jira-applications-to-sql-server-2014-938846861.html]
 # Create a new Service Desk project
 # Create a new SD ticket
 # Add a few comments to the SD ticket to try to trigger the default automation "Transition on comment"
 !Autmation_Bug_Step1.png|thumbnail!

h3. +Expected Result+
 - The transition from the default automation "Transition on comment" should be triggered
 - There should be some information in the log page of the automation "Transition on comment" whenever a new comment is added to the ticket (whether the automation was successful or not)

h3. +Actual Result+
 - The transition is not happening at all
 - The log page of the automation "Transition on comment" is completely empty
 !Autmation_Bug_Step2.png|thumbnail!

h3. +Workaround+

*If you are using JIRA with JAVA 8*

# Stop JIRA
# Move the MS SQL driver mssql-jdbc-7.2.0.jre8.jar from the folder below (please make a backup of it or move it to a temporary folder)
{code:java}
<JIRA_INSTALLATION_FOLDER>/lib
{code}
# Copy the driver  [^mssql-jdbc-6.2.1.jre8.jar] to the same folder
# Start JIRA

*If you are using JIRA with Java 11*

Please note that we do not have a fully tested workaround for JIRA running with Java 11 and involving the replacement of the ms sql jdbc driver.

For this reason, as a workaround, what you can do is either downgrade to your previous version or 4.0.0 of Service Desk, which are both unaffected by this problem. Here are the steps you can follow to execute a downgrade. 8.0.0 might be your best bet since it's a closer down version to what you are on:

# Download the Jira ServiceDesk 4.0.0 Server installer from the link below to install Jira Core 8.0.0 + Service Desk 4.0.0: [Update Jira Service Desk Server|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/service-desk/update]. You will want to click on *View all versions* to get to the 4.0.0 installer for Windows.
# Install Jira Service Desk Server 4.0.0 as a new separate standalone instance as a medium for the 'downgrade'. That being said, there should be a new {{JIRA_Home}}, {{JIRA_Installation}}, and new database for this Service Desk 4.0.0 instance on a new server.
# Once this new instance (4.0.0) is ready, shut it down.
# Allocate adequate application memory as per the [Jira Sizing Guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/enterprise/jira-sizing-guide-461504623.html] and set the flag {{-Djira.downgrade.allowed=true}} on the JSD 4.0.0 instance as per our [Setting properties and options on startup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver070/setting-properties-and-options-on-startup-749383528.html] documentation for your new Windows instance. (i) This is to allow the downgrade to run properly.
# Start the new 4.0.0 instance of Service Desk.
# Take a latest XML backup from your 4.0.1 Service Desk instance that you currently have that is encountering these issues.
# Restore the backup into the new 4.0.0 instance. There will be a message that needs to be acknowledged on the UI after selecting the backup for restoration. Acknowledge it, verify the correct backup file has been chosen and then click on the Restore button again to kick start the restoration process.
# Once this is done, your user will be logged out. Re-login to the 4.0.0 instance, ensure the JSD application is installed and licensed, and that you are able to run automation and send out notifications to customers on some test issues.

h3. +Important Note+

Other Service Desk functionalities are also impacted in Service Desk 4.0.1, when running with a MS SQL Database:
 - SLA panel is empty when new issues are created and SLA does not stop/pause, when using MS SQL with JSD 4.0.1
 - Customer notifications are no longer created and sent when using MS SQL with JSD 4.0.1
fields.summary: Service Desk automation rules are not triggering in Service Desk 4.0.1 when connecting to a MS-SQL database

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

The SLA functionality is not working anymore on JIRA Service Desk 4.0.1 when connected to a MS SQL database.

Known issues so far are the following:
 - when a new ticket is created, the SLA panel is empty
 - when a pause/stop condition is met, the SLA does not pause nor stop

h3. +Steps to reproduce+
 # Install a fresh JSD 4.0.1 instance
 # Connect it to a MS SQL datbase by following the instructions in [Connecting JIRA to MS SQL 2014|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/connecting-jira-applications-to-sql-server-2014-938846861.html]
 # Create a new Service Desk project
 # Create a new SD ticket
 # Notice that the SLA panel is empty
 !SLA_Bug_Step1.png|thumbnail!
 # Go to the SLA configuraiton page, and notice that the *update* button is available, even though no change has been made to the SLA configuration
 !SLA_Bug_Step2.png|thumbnail!
 # Click on the update button and wait until the SLA recalculation is complete
 !SLA_Bug_Step3.png|thumbnail!
 # Refresh the SD ticket, and notice that now the SLA panel is populated
 !SLA_Bug_Step4.png|thumbnail!
 # Resolve the SD ticket to force the SLAs to be completed
 # Notice that none of the SLAs have stopped:
 !SLA_Bug_Step5.png|thumbnail!

h3. +Expected Results+
 - The SLA panel should be populated when the issue is created
 - The SLAs should stop when the stop condition is met

h3. +Actual Results+
 - The SLA panel is empty when the issue is created
 - The SLAs don't stop when the stop condition is met

h3. +Workaround+

*If you are using JIRA with JAVA 8*
 # Stop JIRA
 # Move the MS SQL driver mssql-jdbc-7.2.0.jre8.jar from the folder below (please make a backup of it or move it to a temporary folder)
{code:java}
<JIRA_INSTALLATION_FOLDER>/lib
{code}
 # Copy the driver [^mssql-jdbc-6.2.1.jre8.jar] to the same folder
 # Start JIRA

*If you are using JIRA with Java 11*

Please note that we do not have a fully tested workaround for JIRA running with Java 11 and involving the replacement of the ms sql jdbc driver.

For this reason, as a workaround, what you can do is either downgrade to your previous version or 4.0.0 of Service Desk, which are both unaffected by this problem. Here are the steps you can follow to execute a downgrade. 8.0.0 might be your best bet since it's a closer down version to what you are on:
 # Download the Jira ServiceDesk 4.0.0 Server installer from the link below to install Jira Core 8.0.0 + Service Desk 4.0.0: [Update Jira Service Desk Server|https://www.atlassian.com/software/jira/service-desk/update]. You will want to click on *View all versions* to get to the 4.0.0 installer for Windows.
 # Install Jira Service Desk Server 4.0.0 as a new separate standalone instance as a medium for the 'downgrade'. That being said, there should be a new {{JIRA_Home}}, {{JIRA_Installation}}, and new database for this Service Desk 4.0.0 instance on a new server.
 # Once this new instance (4.0.0) is ready, shut it down.
 # Allocate adequate application memory as per the [Jira Sizing Guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/enterprise/jira-sizing-guide-461504623.html] and set the flag {{-Djira.downgrade.allowed=true}} on the JSD 4.0.0 instance as per our [Setting properties and options on startup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver070/setting-properties-and-options-on-startup-749383528.html] documentation for your new Windows instance. (i) This is to allow the downgrade to run properly.
 # Start the new 4.0.0 instance of Service Desk.
 # Take a latest XML backup from your 4.0.1 Service Desk instance that you currently have that is encountering these issues.
 # Restore the backup into the new 4.0.0 instance. There will be a message that needs to be acknowledged on the UI after selecting the backup for restoration. Acknowledge it, verify the correct backup file has been chosen and then click on the Restore button again to kick start the restoration process.
 # Once this is done, your user will be logged out. Re-login to the 4.0.0 instance, ensure the JSD application is installed and licensed, and that you are able to run automation and send out notifications to customers on some test issues.

h3. +Important Note+

Other Service Desk functionalities are also impacted in Service Desk 4.0.1, when running with a MS SQL Database:
 - Customer notifications are no longer created and sent when using MS SQL with JSD 4.0.1

fields.description:
h2. Summary
When Jira SD try send a webhook via Automation in Service Desk 4.0, the encoding of not Latin characters is broken in the Webhook body.
All non Latin characters in the issue description or title fail to render in the webhook body.

h2. Environment
* Jira 8.0.0 running Jira SD 4.0.0
* Automation is configured to send webhooks.
* Jira uses UTF8, issues have non Latin characters, eg: Cyrillic, Hebrew or Arabic

h2. Steps to Reproduce
* Create a new generic automation rule that sends a webhook if a public comment is added on any issue.
* Configure the webhook to be sent to a webhook test site, eg: https://webhooks.site.
* Enable Debug logging on the package: *org.apache.http*

h2. Expected Results
* Jira SD sends the webhook successfully with all the non Latin characters encoded correctly in the webhook body.

h2. Actual Results
* Jira SD send the webhook but the non Latin characters are not encoded correctly, they display as question marks as below:
JSON content look like
{code:java}
 'description' => '? ??? ????? ???????? ????????? ??? ????? ??????'
{code}
headers are 
{code:java}
  'User-agent' => 'JIRA-Service-Desk-4.0.0 / Apache-HttpClient',
  'Accept' => 'application/json',
  'Content-type' => 'application/json',
{code}
* The data is even not displaying correctly in the debug logs doesn't seem to be a network headers issue:
{code}
2019-03-04 10:25:43,984 PsmqAsyncExecutors-then:thread-2 DEBUG user1 625x2013x1 1hfj2op 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 /rest/api/2/issue/10001/comment [o.apache.http.wire] http-outgoing-45 >> "{"issue":{"id":"10001","self":"http://localhost:1800/jira8
00/rest/api/2/issue/10001","key":"BASITSD-2","fields":{"issuetype":{"self":"http://localhost:1800/jira800/rest/api/2/issuetype/10002","id":"10002","description":"For general IT problems and questions. ......................................................................{"self":"http://localhost:1800/jira800/rest/api/2/statuscategory/4","id":4,"key":"indeterminate","colorName":"yellow","name":"In Progress"}},"components":[],"timeoriginalestimate":null,"description":"?????? ?????? ???? ????? ??????\r\n\r\n[0xa0]\r\n\r\nPlease check this request.","timetracking":{},"attachment":[],"aggregatetimeestimate":null,"summary":"Help me please: ?????? ?????? ???? ????? ??????",................................................................................................
{code}

h2. Notes:
* We try to send same webhook via Core (system webhooks config), all work fine. Trouble only is SD.
* Tried to test the same on Jira 7.13.1 and couldn't reproduce the issue.
* Jira SD 4.0.0 also didn't pick up my proxy settings, unlike what happened in Jira 7.13.1, looks like the Jira SD 4.0.0 is using different implementation now.
fields.summary: Automation sent webhook in containing non-Latin characters, shows encoding Errors 'description' => '? ??? ????? ???????? ????????? ??? ????? ??????'

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

When using the *Add Customer* button from a Service Desk Project Customer page OR the *Service Desk public signup page*, the user is created by using the email address as a username.

This behavior becomes a problem if JIRA is connected to an Active Directory, because JIRA will try to create a new user in the AD by populating the {{sAMAccountName}} attribute with the email address. Since the {{sAMAccountName}} attribute has a character limit of 20, customers will fail to be created if their email address is longer than 20 characters (which is very common), and the following error will be thrown in the logs:
{code}
2018-02-20 02:44:29,434 http-nio-8080-exec-11 ERROR xxxxx XXXxXXXXx1 XXXXXXX XX.XX.XXX.XXX /rest/servicedesk/1/pages/people/customers/pagination/SDS/invite/organisation [c.a.s.internal.user.ServiceDeskUserManagerImpl] Could not create user: atlassiantestuser@test.com com.atlassian.crowd.exception.InvalidUserException: Uncategorized exception occured during LDAP processing; nested exception is javax.naming.NamingException: [LDAP: error code 80 - 00000523: SysErr: DSID-031A12C8, problem 22 (Invalid argument), data 0^@]; remaining name 'cn=atlassiantestuser@test.com,ou=people,ou=users,ou=root ou,dc=test,dc=com'
{code}


h3. +Suggested solution+

Improve the customer creation design, e.g *Add Customer* button so that the Project Admin can set the username of the newly created user, instead of just entering an email address and letting JIRA automatically set this email address as the username.

h3. +Note+

(!) This issue will happen, no matter what the user name attribute is mapped to in the AD configuration in JIRA. Even if it's mapped to a different attribute such as {{userPrincipalName}}, JIRA will still populate the {{sAMAccountName}} attribute.

h3. +Workaround+

# First, create the user from the page ⚙ > User Management > Users > Create User
## With this creation method, you'll be able to decide what the username attribute should be and use a string which is less than 20 characters
# Then add the user to the project customers by going to the Project's Customers page, clicking on *Add Customer* and using the username of the user created in the first step

OR

Asking customers to sign up from Jira's sign up page.
fields.summary: Creating new customers failed when connected to Active Directory if username is longer than 20 characters

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

When a Service Desk project contains a high number of issues (for example more than 20k), the SLA recalculation might get stuck or take a long time after editing an SLA configuration.
h3. +Steps to reproduce+
 - Create a Service Desk project with at least 20k open issues
 - Make a change to an existing SLA in the project via the page *Project Settings > SLAs*, in order to trigger the re-calculation of this SLA for the entire project

(!) Note that this issue has not been reproduced on Atlassian side, but it has been reported by some customers.
h3. +Actual Result+

The SLA recalculation takes a lot of time to complete, and from the UI it looks like it's stuck since the progression bar does not seem to progress.
 (!) Note that the time it takes for the recalculation to complete varies depending:
 - on the customer's environment
 - the length of the history of issues for which the SLA needs to be recalculated
 - the number of goals in the SLA configuration
 - the number of SLAs configured in the project

h3. +Expected Result+

The recalculation of the SLA should be faster (although it is difficult to tell how long it should take as it depends on many factors, see above).
h3. +Workaround+

No known workaround.
fields.summary: Extremely slow SLA recalculation time when a Service Desk project contains a high number of issues

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, the Service Desk Mail handlers checks 4 places in order to determine if it should add a comment to an existing issue:
* {{Subject}} header - trying to find the issue key and add a comment there
* {{In-Reply-To}} header - trying to match the Message-ID value (with the ones in the {{notificationinstance}} table) in order to find the issue ID to add a comment to
* {{References}} header - same as the previous one
* {{Message-ID}} header - same as the previous one

If none of them points to the issue - a new issue should be created

Also, the Mail Handler does not look for the issue key in the content of the email.


h3. Suggested Solution

Allow the Service Desk Mail Handler to look for an existing issue key in the content of the email, in case it is unable to match the email with an existing issue based on the 4 criteria mentioned above.
fields.summary: Allow the Service Desk Mail Handler to look for an existing issue key in the content of the email

fields.description:
Summary
If a Service Desk project has more than 100 request types on a single Group, then only a maximum of 100 request types will be displayed in the administration section of the project. There is no pagination on this page, making the request types not included in the first 100 not available for editing.

Steps to Reproduce
* Create more than 100 request types inside the same group in a Service Desk project.

Expected Results
You are able to view every single existing request type inside this group.

Actual Results
You will only view 100 request types at most - the displayed request types will be the ones that were created last, so older request types and the default ones that come with a Service Desk project will not be visible. 

Workaround
If you need to make changes to the request type, you can reach the configuration page by copying the URL from another's request type edit page, changing the ID displayed at the URL to match the request type that is not visible through the UI. The following SQL query can be used to identify the request type ID:

{code:sql}
select vptfm."ID", vptfm."NAME", vpt."NAME" from "AO_54307E_VIEWPORTFORM" vptfm
join "AO_54307E_VIEWPORT" vpt on vptfm."VIEWPORT_ID" = vpt."ID"
where vpt."NAME" = '%PROJECT NAME%'
and vptfm."NAME" = '%REQUEST TYPE NAME%'
{code}

Once you have the ID, change the ID in the URL as exemplified below:

# We want to reach the request type with ID 1234.
# Accessing another request type will give us the following URL: {{https://JIRA-URL/servicedesk/admin/TEST/request-types/request-type/128}}
# We can access request type 1234 by changing the last digits in the URL, matching the correct ID: {{https://JIRA-URL/servicedesk/admin/TEST/request-types/request-type/1234}}
fields.summary: Request types admin page displays a maximum of 100 request types inside a group

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

If a JQL filter is referring to another filter involving SLA JQL functions, it will show different results to agent and non-agent users.


h3. +Steps to reproduce+

- Create a 1st JQL filter involving SQL functions, for example:
{code}
project = SD_TEST AND ("Test SLA" = breached() OR "Test SLA" != breached())
{code}
- Let's call this filter "SLA Not Empty"
- Create a 2nd JQL filter which is referring to the 1st JQL filter, for example:
{code}
project = SD_TEST AND filter != "SLA Not Empty"
{code}
- Let's call this filter "SLA Empty"
- Create 2 JIRA accounts:
-- Make the 1st account an Agent by granting this user a Service Desk license
-- Make the 2nd account a non-Agent by granting this user a JIRA Core or Software license
- Open the 1st filter "SLA Not Empty" with each user.
-- Verify that this filter is viewable by the Agent:
 !FilterViewedByAnAgent_NoErrorMessage.png|thumbnail! 
-- Verify that this filter is non-viewable by the Agent and that the following error is thrown, which is expected since non-agent users don't have access to any SLA functionality:
{code}You must be an agent to use the SLA JQL functions.{code}
 !FilterViewedByAnonAgent_ErrorMessage.png|thumbnail! 
- Open the 2nd filter with the Agent user
 !FilterViewedByAnAgent.png|thumbnail! 
- Open the 2nd filter with the non-Agent user

h3. +Actual Result+

The 2nd filter is not only viewable by the non-Agent user, but it shows a different number of results (82 results, vs 73 results for the Agent user):
 !FilterViewedByAnonAgent.png|thumbnail! 

h3. +Expected Result+

The 2nd filter should not be viewable by the non-agent user, and the following error should be thrown, since non-agent users don't have access to any SLA functionality:
{code}You must be an agent to use the SLA JQL functions.{code}

*OR*

Both users (agent or not) should see the same results when viewing the same filter (as long as they have the same permissions to view these issues).

h3. +Workaround+

- Provide the non-agent user with a Service Desk license, so that the SLA functions can work as expected for this user
- Or use a filter that does not involve any SLA JQL function to ensure that both agents and non-agents see the same results
fields.summary: Filters involving SLA JQL functions show different results to agent and non-agent users

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Service Desk Server*. Using *JIRA Service Desk Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDCLOUD-8420].
  {panel}
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, it is not possible to blacklist specific email addresses in a Service Desk project to prevent specific emails addresses from being sent customer notifications.

It can be a problem when Service Desk issues are created automatically by email by a monitoring system, and then the monitoring system gets spammed with notifications coming from the Service Desk issue.

Disabling all the customer notifications within the project is one way to workaround the situation, but it does not apply in the case where we want to add participants to these Service Desk issues and we want them to receive notifications (but not the monitoring system).


h3. Suggested Solution

Allow allows to blacklist specific email addresses for outgoing mail:
- either for the whole JIRA instance via the page ⚙ > System > Outgoing Mail
- or for a specific Service Desk
fields.summary: Ability to blacklist e-mail addresses for sending email messages (outgoing notifications)

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When editing a Jira Service Desk report filter, every time the report filter is edited, it adds (concatenate) the project name to the JQL query. Multiple edits will add the project key every time the Edit button is clicked. Here is an example 
  
 {{project = "TST" AND project = "TST" AND component = "Public website"}}
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # On a Service Desk project, Go to Reports
 # Click Edit on a report
 # Click Edit on a Series
 # Click Save
 # Click Edit again
 # Note that the project key has been added to the JQL
 # The project key will keep being added to the JQL if steps 3-4 are repeated.

h3. Expected Results

The series JQL filter should keep the same query after saving.
h3. Actual Results

the project key is added to the JQL every time the JQL is edited.
h3. Workaround

Delete the extraneous 'Project="<project_key>"' every time the filter is edited.
fields.summary: Editing a report series keeps adding the project key to the JQL filter

fields.description:
h3. +Issue description+

The "Send email" automation rule does not send any email on the "Status Changed" event if the previous status has the same "Customer Facing" name as the new status.
h3. +Steps to reproduce+
 # Create a new workflow that has a transition going from a status called "In progress - L1" a status called "Assigned - L2"
 # Create a new Request Type using an issue type associated to this workflow, click on the "Workflow Statuses" tab, and modify the customer facing status ("status name to show customer") corresponding to "In progress - L1" and "Assigned - L2" to be the same: "In Progress"
 !Bug_RequestType_SameStatus.png|thumbnail!
 # Create a new automation rule that sends an email when the status is changed to "Assigned - L2"
 !Bug_AutomationRule.png|thumbnail!
 # Create a new Service Desk request using the workflow above
 # Transition the issue from "In progress - L1" to "Assigned - L2"
 # Wait for the customer notification to be sent

h3. +Actual Result+

The email that should have been triggered by the automation is not sent. Instead, we only see the regular customer notifications that are triggered when the status of an issue is changed:
 !Bug_NotificationReceived.png|thumbnail!

However, in the automation log, it "looks like" the email should have been sent (although it's not the case):
 !Bug_AutomationLogs.png|thumbnail!
h3. +Expected Result+

The email should have been sent from the automation rule, no matter what the previous status was, even if the previous customer facing status was the same, since this is what the automation logs are reporting.

Alternatively, the logs should display a failure instead of a success, with the reason why the email was not sent.
h3. +Workaround+

Use different names for 2 customer facing statuses:
 !Bug_RequestType_DifferentStatus.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: The "Send email" automation rule does not send any email for a specific configuration

fields.description:
h3. Summary
It appears that if we removed a status from JIRA where the previous step was from a Status with approval, the tickets that go through the flow (Create > approval > will be deleted status > another status) would not be able to be viewed through the portal.

h3. Steps to Replicate
# Create a new status e.g. "After Approval"
# Assign it to a Workflow used by a Service Desk project.
# Then set the Status Incoming and Outgoing transition.
# Set the Incoming status to have Approval configured.
# Publish the workflow.
# Create a ticket towards the workflow from the Portal side.
# Let it go through the flow (Approval Status > After Approval > Any Status)
# Delete the "After Approval" status from the workflow.
# Delete it completely from the "Statuses" page.
# Open the previous ticket from the Portal.

h3. Expected Result
The ticket will be accessible as usual.

h3. Actual Result.
A 500 NPE Error will be showing.

h3. Workaround
The only workaround at the moment is to recreate the status again and set the ID in the database to the same as the old ID
fields.summary: 500 NullPointerException error after deleting a status

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When a non-agent user creates an issue directly into the JSD project, they will be presented with the 'Request participants' field. However, as per mentioned in [the documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver/adding-request-participants-939926441.html#Addingrequestparticipants-Addparticipantstoanissue], only agents are allowed to add participants directly into the issue. JIRA recognizes this and prevents the action by presenting a pop-up with an error message:
 !RequestParticipant.png|thumbnail! 
However, the error message is confusing as it is not stating why the action is prevented.

Furthermore, the error message pop-up will constantly appear even after dismissing it. This prevents the user from continuing with the request creation. One way to avoid it is to refresh the page which will lose the prior data in the creation screen.

h3. Replication process:
# Create a Service Desk project
# Grant a non-agent user the 'Create Issue' permission other than "Service desk customer - portal access"
# As the non-agent user, create an issue for the SD project
# Try to fill in a user in 'Request participant' field
# Gets a pop-up error message

h3. Suggested Solution
* Give better error message with a direct reason for the error (e.g.: "You are not an agent in this Service Desk project")
* Hide the 'Request participants' field from non-agent users

h3. Workaround 
* Refresh the page (Note: will lose the data in the create screen)
* Prevent non-agent  users from the 'Create Issue' permission other than "Service desk customer - portal access"
** This will ensure the non-agent users will only create requests from the Customer Portal
fields.summary: Change the error message when non-agent tries to add request participant directly into the issue
